summary: Email chain from March 25, 2019, discussing concerns about Jeffrey Epstein being sighted on the Palm Beach bike path with a young girl. The correspondence involves a concerned citizen reporting these sightings to the DOJ Criminal Division and referencing communication with a former Palm Beach Police Chief about the original 2005 Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Registered sex offender, subject of sightings
persons.context: Described as a level 3 registered sex offender sighted multiple times riding a bicycle on the Palm Beach bike path accompanied by a young girl in late 2018 and early 2019.

events.title: Original Epstein investigation in Palm Beach
events.description: Reference to the original investigation into Jeffrey Epstein conducted by the Palm Beach Police Department.

events.title: Sighting of Epstein on Palm Beach bike path
events.description: Reported sighting of Jeffrey Epstein riding a bicycle on the Palm Beach bike path accompanied by a young girl.

events.title: Extended date for Epstein sighting report
events.description: Mention that the reporting period for Epstein sightings was extended to include February 21, 2019.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was sighted multiple times in late 2018 and early 2019 riding a bicycle on the Palm Beach bike path accompanied by a young girl described as Caucasian, brunette, wearing a ponytail, and not looking older than 18.
The source of the sightings was afraid to contact police directly and instead reported through an intermediary to the DOJ Criminal Division.
The Palm Beach Police Department had no knowledge of the incident when contacted in March 2019, despite it being the third sighting in a six-month period.
The email references that registered sex offenders are not allowed on Palm Beach bike paths, accompanied or unaccompanied, and that such a sighting should constitute a police matter.
The correspondence indicates video surveillance tapes on the bike path are reviewed every three months and then erased, creating potential evidence preservation issues.
